a singular subject takes a singular verb.English Rule: A singular subject takes a singular verb
a singular subject takes a singular verb.When to Use: When subject is singular (he, she, it, one person/thing)

a plural subject takes a plural verb.English Rule: A plural subject takes a plural verb
a plural subject takes a plural verb.When to Use: When subject is plural (they, we, multiple people/things)

use 'is/was' with singular subjects.When to Use: With he, she, it, or singular nouns

use 'are/were' with plural subjects.When to Use: With they, we, you, or plural nouns

add 's' or 'es' to verbs with he/she/it.English Rule: Add 's' or 'es' to verbs with he/she/it in present tense
add 's' or 'es' to verbs with he/she/it.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన కాలంలో he/she/it తో క్రియలకు 's' లేదా 'es' జోడించండి
add 's' or 'es' to verbs with he/she/it.When to Use: In present simple with third person singular

don't add 's/es' with i, you, we, they.English Rule: Don't add 's/es' with I, you, we, they
don't add 's/es' with i, you, we, they.Telugu Rule: I, you, we, they తో 's/es' జోడించవద్దు
don't add 's/es' with i, you, we, they.When to Use: In present simple with all subjects except he/she/it

collective nouns can be singular or plur.English Rule: Collective nouns can be singular or plural
collective nouns can be singular or plur.Telugu Rule: సమూహ నామవాచకాలు ఏకవచనం లేదా బహువచనం కావచ్చు
collective nouns can be singular or plur.When to Use: With words like team, family, group
collective nouns can be singular or plur.Incorrect Example: The team are winning. (if treating as unit)

everyone, somebody, nobody take singular.English Rule: Everyone, somebody, nobody take singular verbs
everyone, somebody, nobody take singular.Telugu Rule: Everyone, somebody, nobody ఏకవచన క్రియలను తీసుకుంటాయి

neither/either takes singular verb when.English Rule: Neither/either takes singular verb when alone
neither/either takes singular verb when.Telugu Rule: Neither/either ఒంటరిగా ఉన్నప్పుడు ఏకవచన క్రియను తీసుకుంటుంది
neither/either takes singular verb when.When to Use: When neither/either stands alone as subject

subjects joined by 'and' take plural ver.English Rule: Subjects joined by 'and' take plural verb
subjects joined by 'and' take plural ver.Telugu Rule: 'and' తో కలిపిన కర్తలు బహువచన క్రియను తీసుకుంటాయి
subjects joined by 'and' take plural ver.When to Use: When two or more subjects connected by 'and'

with 'or/nor', verb agrees with nearest.English Rule: With 'or/nor', verb agrees with nearest subject
with 'or/nor', verb agrees with nearest.Example: Neither he nor they are coming.
with 'or/nor', verb agrees with nearest.Incorrect Example: Neither the students nor the teacher were ready.
with 'or/nor', verb agrees with nearest.Correct Example: Neither he nor they are coming.

there is + singular, there are + plural.English Rule: There is + singular, There are + plural
there is + singular, there are + plural.Telugu Rule: There is + ఏకవచనం, There are + బహువచనం
there is + singular, there are + plural.Example: There is a book. There are books.
there is + singular, there are + plural.Incorrect Example: Either the teacher or the students is ready.
there is + singular, there are + plural.Correct Example: There is a book. There are books.

title of books/movies takes singular ver.English Rule: Title of books/movies takes singular verb
title of books/movies takes singular ver.When to Use: With titles, even if they look plural

each, every + singular noun takes singul.English Rule: Each, every + singular noun takes singular verb
each, every + singular noun takes singul.Telugu Rule: Each, every + ఏకవచన నామవాచకం ఏకవచన క్రియను తీసుకుంటుంది

use 'a' before consonant sounds.When to Use: Before words starting with consonant sounds

use 'an' before vowel sounds.When to Use: Before words starting with vowel sounds

use 'the' for specific things known to s.English Rule: Use 'the' for specific things known to speaker and listener
use 'the' for specific things known to s.Telugu Rule: మాట్లాడేవారికి మరియు వినేవారికి తెలిసిన నిర్దిష్ట విషయాల కోసం 'the' ఉపయోగించండి
use 'the' for specific things known to s.When to Use: When both know what you're talking about
use 'the' for specific things known to s.Example: The sun rises in the east.
use 'the' for specific things known to s.Correct Example: The sun rises in the east.

use 'a/an' for non-specific things (one.English Rule: Use 'a/an' for non-specific things (one of many)
use 'a/an' for non-specific things (one.When to Use: When talking about any one thing, not specific

use 'the' before superlatives.When to Use: With words like best, worst, tallest

use 'the' before country names with 'of'.When to Use: With United States, United Kingdom, etc.

don't use articles before meals in gener.English Rule: Don't use articles before meals in general

don't use 'the' before languages.Incorrect Example: The apple is a healthy fruit.

use 'the' when something is mentioned se.English Rule: Use 'the' when something is mentioned second time
use 'the' when something is mentioned se.Example: I saw a dog. The dog was brown.
use 'the' when something is mentioned se.Correct Example: I saw a dog. The dog was brown.

don't use articles before proper nouns (.English Rule: Don't use articles before proper nouns (names)

use 'the' before family names (plural).When to Use: When talking about a whole family

use 'the' with adjectives to make them p.English Rule: Use 'the' with adjectives to make them plural nouns
use 'the' with adjectives to make them p.When to Use: To refer to groups of people

use present simple for habits and routin.Example: I wake up at 6 AM every day.

use present simple for universal truths.Example: The sun rises in the east.

use present simple for universal truths.Correct Example: The sun rises in the east.

don't use continuous with stative verbs.When to Use: With know, love, hate, want, need, etc.

use present perfect for past actions wit.Example: I have finished my homework (now I'm free).
use present perfect for past actions wit.Correct Example: I have finished my homework (now I'm free).

present perfect: have/has + v3.When to Use: For completed actions with present connection

use present perfect with just, already,.English Rule: Use present perfect with just, already, yet

use past continuous for interrupted acti.Telugu Rule: అంతరాయం కలిగిన చర్యల కోసం గత నిరంతర కాలం ఉపయోగించండి

future continuous: will be + v1+ing.Correct Example: I will be working at 5 PM tomorrow.

use 'will' for instant decisions.When to Use: For decisions made at moment of speaking

don't use 'will' after if, when, before,.Example: When he comes (not 'will come'), I will tell him.

use 'may' for permission or possibility.Example: May I come in? It may rain.
use 'may' for permission or possibility.Incorrect Example: He is qualified at this job.
use 'may' for permission or possibility.Correct Example: May I come in? It may rain.

use 'must' for strong obligation or cert.English Rule: Use 'must' for strong obligation or certainty
use 'must' for strong obligation or cert.Example: You must study. He must be tired.
use 'must' for strong obligation or cert.Correct Example: You must study. He must be tired.

use 'would' for polite requests or past.English Rule: Use 'would' for polite requests or past habits
use 'would' for polite requests or past.Telugu Rule: మర్యాదపూర్వక అభ్యర్థనలు లేదా గత అలవాట్లకు 'would' ఉపయోగించండి
use 'would' for polite requests or past.When to Use: For politeness or repeated past actions
use 'would' for polite requests or past.Example: Would you help? He would visit daily.
use 'would' for polite requests or past.Correct Example: Would you help? He would visit daily.

use 'ought to' for moral duty or advice.English Rule: Use 'ought to' for moral duty or advice
use 'ought to' for moral duty or advice.Telugu Rule: నైతిక కర్తవ్యం లేదా సలహా కోసం 'ought to' ఉపయోగించండి
use 'ought to' for moral duty or advice.When to Use: For what is right to do

modal + base form of verb (no 'to', no -.English Rule: Modal + base form of verb (no 'to', no -s/-ing/-ed)
modal + base form of verb (no 'to', no -.Example: can go (not 'can to go' or 'can goes')
modal + base form of verb (no 'to', no -.Correct Example: can go (not 'can to go' or 'can goes')

can't/cannot for inability or prohibitio.When to Use: For what is not possible or allowed
can't/cannot for inability or prohibitio.Example: I can't swim. You cannot smoke here.
can't/cannot for inability or prohibitio.Correct Example: I can't swim. You cannot smoke here.

don't have to/need not for no necessity.English Rule: Don't have to/need not for no necessity
don't have to/need not for no necessity.Telugu Rule: అవసరం లేనప్పుడు don't have to/need not

have to/has to for external obligation.English Rule: Have to/has to for external obligation

use 'shall' for offers and suggestions (.Example: Shall I help? Shall we dance?
use 'shall' for offers and suggestions (.Correct Example: Shall I help? Shall we dance?

would you like for polite offers.English Rule: Would you like for polite offers
would you like for polite offers.Telugu Rule: మర్యాదపూర్వక ప్రతిపాదనల కోసం would you like

could have/would have + v3 for past poss.English Rule: Could have/would have + V3 for past possibilities
could have/would have + v3 for past poss.Telugu Rule: గత అవకాశాల కోసం could have/would have + V3

must have + v3 for past certainty.English Rule: Must have + V3 for past certainty

may/might have + v3 for past possibility.English Rule: May/might have + V3 for past possibility

should have + v3 for past advice/regret.English Rule: Should have + V3 for past advice/regret
should have + v3 for past advice/regret.When to Use: For what was right to do but wasn't done

yes/no questions: auxiliary + subject +.English Rule: Yes/No questions: Auxiliary + subject + main verb
yes/no questions: auxiliary + subject +.Telugu Rule: అవును/కాదు ప్రశ్నలు: సహాయక క్రియ + కర్త + ప్రధాన క్రియ
yes/no questions: auxiliary + subject +.Example: Are you ready? Do you like it?
yes/no questions: auxiliary + subject +.Correct Example: Are you ready? Do you like it?

use 'do/does' for present simple questio.When to Use: With action verbs in present tense
use 'do/does' for present simple questio.Example: Do you work? Does he study?
use 'do/does' for present simple questio.Correct Example: Do you work? Does he study?

use 'did' for past simple questions.Example: Did you go? Did she call?
use 'did' for past simple questions.Correct Example: Did you go? Did she call?

wh-questions: wh-word + auxiliary + subj.Telugu Rule: WH-ప్రశ్నలు: WH-పదం + సహాయక క్రియ + కర్త + క్రియ
wh-questions: wh-word + auxiliary + subj.When to Use: With what, when, where, why, how, who

use 'what' for things and actions.When to Use: To ask about things or information

use 'how' for manner or method.Incorrect Example: That is the person who I saw.

use 'how much' for uncountable quantitie.Incorrect Example: This is the book who I read.

use 'how long' for duration.Example: How long have you lived here?
use 'how long' for duration.Correct Example: How long have you lived here?

subject questions: wh-word + verb (no au.Telugu Rule: కర్త ప్రశ్నలు: WH-పదం + క్రియ (సహాయక క్రియ లేకుండా)

adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, othe.English Rule: Adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, other adverbs
adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, othe.Telugu Rule: క్రియా విశేషణాలు క్రియలు, విశేషణాలు, ఇతర క్రియా విశేషణాలను వర్ణిస్తాయి
adverbs describe verbs, adjectives, othe.When to Use: To describe actions or modify adjectives

adjective order: opinion-size-age-shape-.Example: a beautiful big old round red Italian wooden dining table
adjective order: opinion-size-age-shape-.Correct Example: a beautiful big old round red Italian wooden dining table

add '-ly' to make adverbs from adjective.English Rule: Add '-ly' to make adverbs from adjectives
add '-ly' to make adverbs from adjective.Telugu Rule: విశేషణాల నుండి క్రియా విశేషణాలు చేయడానికి '-ly' జోడించండి

good (adjective) vs well (adverb).When to Use: Good with nouns, well with verbs

superlative: -est/most for comparing thr.English Rule: Superlative: -est/most for comparing three or more
superlative: -est/most for comparing thr.Telugu Rule: అత్యున్నత: మూడు లేదా అంతకంటే ఎక్కువ పోల్చడానికి -est/most

adverbs of frequency: always, usually, o.English Rule: Adverbs of frequency: always, usually, often, sometimes, rarely, never
adverbs of frequency: always, usually, o.Telugu Rule: ఫ్రీక్వెన్సీ క్రియా విశేషణాలు: always, usually, often, sometimes, rarely, never

place adverbs of frequency before main v.English Rule: Place adverbs of frequency before main verb
place adverbs of frequency before main v.Telugu Rule: ప్రధాన క్రియకు ముందు ఫ్రీక్వెన్సీ క్రియా విశేషణాలను ఉంచండి

place adverbs of frequency after 'be' ve.English Rule: Place adverbs of frequency after 'be' verb
place adverbs of frequency after 'be' ve.Telugu Rule: 'be' క్రియ తర్వాత ఫ్రీక్వెన్సీ క్రియా విశేషణాలను ఉంచండి
place adverbs of frequency after 'be' ve.Incorrect Example: I am used to wake up early.

adverbs of manner usually go at end of s.English Rule: Adverbs of manner usually go at end of sentence
adverbs of manner usually go at end of s.Telugu Rule: విధాన క్రియా విశేషణాలు సాధారణంగా వాక్య చివర వెళ్తాయి

very intensifies adjectives and adverbs.Telugu Rule: Very విశేషణాలు మరియు క్రియా విశేషణాలను తీవ్రతరం చేస్తుంది

zero conditional: if + present simple, p.English Rule: Zero conditional: If + present simple, present simple
zero conditional: if + present simple, p.Telugu Rule: శూన్య షరతు: If + వర్తమాన సాధారణం, వర్తమాన సాధారణం
zero conditional: if + present simple, p.Example: If you heat water, it boils.
zero conditional: if + present simple, p.Correct Example: If you heat water, it boils.

first conditional: if + present simple,.English Rule: First conditional: If + present simple, will + V1
first conditional: if + present simple,.Telugu Rule: మొదటి షరతు: If + వర్తమాన సాధారణం, will + V1
first conditional: if + present simple,.Example: If it rains, I will stay home.
first conditional: if + present simple,.Correct Example: If it rains, I will stay home.

second conditional: if + past simple, wo.English Rule: Second conditional: If + past simple, would + V1
second conditional: if + past simple, wo.Telugu Rule: రెండవ షరతు: If + గత సాధారణం, would + V1
second conditional: if + past simple, wo.Example: If I had money, I would buy a car.
second conditional: if + past simple, wo.Correct Example: If I had money, I would buy a car.

third conditional: if + past perfect, wo.English Rule: Third conditional: If + past perfect, would have + V3
third conditional: if + past perfect, wo.Telugu Rule: మూడవ షరతు: If + గత పరిపూర్ణం, would have + V3
third conditional: if + past perfect, wo.Example: If I had studied, I would have passed.
third conditional: if + past perfect, wo.Correct Example: If I had studied, I would have passed.

use 'unless' to mean 'if not'.Example: Unless you study, you will fail.
use 'unless' to mean 'if not'.Correct Example: Unless you study, you will fail.

use 'if' for condition, 'when' for certa.When to Use: If for maybe, when for sure
use 'if' for condition, 'when' for certa.Example: If he comes vs When he comes
use 'if' for condition, 'when' for certa.Correct Example: If he comes vs When he comes

use 'were' (not 'was') in second conditi.English Rule: Use 'were' (not 'was') in second conditional with I/he/she/it

mixed conditionals combine different tim.When to Use: When condition and result are in different times
mixed conditionals combine different tim.Example: If I had studied (past), I would be happy now (present).
mixed conditionals combine different tim.Correct Example: If I had studied (past), I would be happy now (present).

use 'as long as' for condition with dura.English Rule: Use 'as long as' for condition with duration
use 'as long as' for condition with dura.Telugu Rule: వ్యవధితో షరతు కోసం 'as long as' ఉపయోగించండి
use 'as long as' for condition with dura.Example: You can stay as long as you want.
use 'as long as' for condition with dura.Correct Example: You can stay as long as you want.

use 'provided/providing that' for condit.Example: You can go, provided you finish work.
use 'provided/providing that' for condit.Incorrect Example: If it will rain, I stay home.
use 'provided/providing that' for condit.Correct Example: You can go, provided you finish work.

use 'in case' for precaution.Example: Take umbrella in case it rains.
use 'in case' for precaution.Incorrect Example: If I would have money, I buy it.
use 'in case' for precaution.Correct Example: Take umbrella in case it rains.

first conditional shows real possibility.When to Use: When something is likely to happen
first conditional shows real possibility.Example: If I see him, I will tell him.
first conditional shows real possibility.Incorrect Example: If I will see him, I will tell him.
first conditional shows real possibility.Correct Example: If I see him, I will tell him.

second conditional shows imagination/unl.Example: If I were you, I would accept.
second conditional shows imagination/unl.Incorrect Example: If I would be rich, I help.
second conditional shows imagination/unl.Correct Example: If I were you, I would accept.

third conditional shows regret about pas.English Rule: Third conditional shows regret about past
third conditional shows regret about pas.Telugu Rule: మూడవ షరతు గతం గురించి పశ్చాత్తాపాన్ని చూపిస్తుంది
third conditional shows regret about pas.When to Use: For past situations that can't be changed
third conditional shows regret about pas.Example: If I had known, I would have helped.
third conditional shows regret about pas.Incorrect Example: If I would have studied, I would pass.
third conditional shows regret about pas.Correct Example: If I had known, I would have helped.

passive voice: object becomes subject +.English Rule: Passive voice: Object becomes subject + be + V3
passive voice: object becomes subject +.Telugu Rule: కర్మ వాచకం: కర్మ కర్తగా మారుతుంది + be + V3
passive voice: object becomes subject +.When to Use: When focus is on action or receiver
passive voice: object becomes subject +.Example: The book was written by him.
passive voice: object becomes subject +.Incorrect Example: If he would have came, we met.
passive voice: object becomes subject +.Correct Example: The book was written by him.

use passive when doer is unknown.English Rule: Use passive when doer is unknown
use passive when doer is unknown.When to Use: When we don't know who did it
use passive when doer is unknown.Incorrect Example: Unless you will not study, you fail.

use passive when doer is unimportant.English Rule: Use passive when doer is unimportant
use passive when doer is unimportant.Telugu Rule: చేసేవారు ముఖ్యం కానప్పుడు కర్మ వాచకం ఉపయోగించండి
use passive when doer is unimportant.When to Use: When action matters more than doer
use passive when doer is unimportant.Incorrect Example: If I am you, I would go.

use 'by' to show the doer in passive.English Rule: Use 'by' to show the doer in passive
use 'by' to show the doer in passive.Incorrect Example: I wish I have more time.

present simple passive: am/is/are + v3.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన సాధారణ కర్మ వాచకం: am/is/are + V3

past simple passive: was/were + v3.Telugu Rule: గత సాధారణ కర్మ వాచకం: was/were + V3

future passive: will be + v3.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్ కర్మ వాచకం: will be + V3
future passive: will be + v3.Incorrect Example: Provided you will come, I go.

present perfect passive: has/have been +.English Rule: Present perfect passive: has/have been + V3
present perfect passive: has/have been +.Telugu Rule: వర్తమాన పరిపూర్ణ కర్మ వాచకం: has/have been + V3

modal passive: modal + be + v3.Telugu Rule: మోడల్ కర్మ వాచకం: modal + be + V3
modal passive: modal + be + v3.Example: It can be done. It must be finished.
modal passive: modal + be + v3.Correct Example: It can be done. It must be finished.

active voice is more direct and clear.English Rule: Active voice is more direct and clear
active voice is more direct and clear.Telugu Rule: కర్త వాచకం మరింత ప్రత్యక్షంగా మరియు స్పష్టంగా ఉంటుంది
active voice is more direct and clear.When to Use: Prefer active unless specific reason for passive
active voice is more direct and clear.Example: I wrote the letter (better than 'was written by me')
active voice is more direct and clear.Incorrect Example: Even if it rains, we will went.
active voice is more direct and clear.Correct Example: I wrote the letter (better than 'was written by me')

remove quotation marks in reported speec.English Rule: Remove quotation marks in reported speech
remove quotation marks in reported speec.When to Use: When converting direct to indirect speech
remove quotation marks in reported speec.Example: She said, 'I'm happy' → She said she was happy
remove quotation marks in reported speec.Incorrect Example: If it would rain yesterday, we stayed.
remove quotation marks in reported speec.Correct Example: She said, 'I'm happy' → She said she was happy

use 'that' after reporting verbs (option.Incorrect Example: Were I you, I will go.

change pronouns according to context.Example: She said, 'I like it' → She said she liked it
change pronouns according to context.Incorrect Example: Had I know, I told you.
change pronouns according to context.Correct Example: She said, 'I like it' → She said she liked it

past simple changes to past perfect.English Rule: Past simple changes to past perfect
past simple changes to past perfect.Example: He said, 'I went' → He said he had gone
past simple changes to past perfect.Correct Example: He said, 'I went' → He said he had gone

will changes to would.Example: She said, 'I will come' → She said she would come
will changes to would.Incorrect Example: He said me that he will come.
will changes to would.Correct Example: She said, 'I will come' → She said she would come

can changes to could.Example: He said, 'I can help' → He said he could help
can changes to could.Incorrect Example: She asked that I am ready.
can changes to could.Correct Example: He said, 'I can help' → He said he could help

change time expressions: today → that da.English Rule: Change time expressions: today → that day, tomorrow → next day
change time expressions: today → that da.Telugu Rule: సమయ వ్యక్తీకరణలను మార్చండి: today → that day, tomorrow → next day
change time expressions: today → that da.Example: She said, 'I'll come tomorrow' → She said she would come the next day
change time expressions: today → that da.Incorrect Example: He said he will come tomorrow.
change time expressions: today → that da.Correct Example: She said, 'I'll come tomorrow' → She said she would come the next day

use 'tell' with object, 'say' without.Example: He told me (not 'said me'). He said to me.
use 'tell' with object, 'say' without.Correct Example: He told me (not 'said me'). He said to me.

questions in reported speech: ask + if/w.English Rule: Questions in reported speech: ask + if/whether or WH-word
questions in reported speech: ask + if/w.Telugu Rule: పరోక్ష వాక్యంలో ప్రశ్నలు: ask + if/whether లేదా WH-పదం
questions in reported speech: ask + if/w.Example: He asked, 'Are you ready?' → He asked if I was ready
questions in reported speech: ask + if/w.Incorrect Example: He asked me where do I live.
questions in reported speech: ask + if/w.Correct Example: He asked, 'Are you ready?' → He asked if I was ready

don't use double negatives.When to Use: Avoid two negatives in same clause
don't use double negatives.Example: I don't have anything (not 'don't have nothing')
don't use double negatives.Correct Example: I don't have anything (not 'don't have nothing')

use 'some' in positive, 'any' in negativ.Example: I have some books. I don't have any books.
use 'some' in positive, 'any' in negativ.Incorrect Example: He said that he can swim.
use 'some' in positive, 'any' in negativ.Correct Example: I have some books. I don't have any books.

use 'some' in offers and requests.Incorrect Example: She asked me that I like coffee.

use 'much' with uncountable, 'many' with.Incorrect Example: He told to me the story.

use 'few/a few' with countable nouns.When to Use: few = not many (negative), a few = some (positive)
use 'few/a few' with countable nouns.Example: few books (not many), a few books (some)
use 'few/a few' with countable nouns.Correct Example: few books (not many), a few books (some)

use 'little/a little' with uncountable n.When to Use: little = not much, a little = some
use 'little/a little' with uncountable n.Incorrect Example: He ordered me that I should leave.

both, either, neither - for two things.English Rule: Both, either, neither - for two things
both, either, neither - for two things.Example: Both books, either option, neither choice
both, either, neither - for two things.Incorrect Example: She requested me that help her.
both, either, neither - for two things.Correct Example: Both books, either option, neither choice

all, every, each - usage differences.When to Use: all = group, every = each one, each = individual
all, every, each - usage differences.Example: all students, every student, each student
all, every, each - usage differences.Correct Example: all students, every student, each student

make/do - different uses.Incorrect Example: She advised me that I should sleep.

see/look/watch differences.When to Use: see = general, look = direct attention, watch = movement
see/look/watch differences.Example: see a bird, look at photo, watch TV
see/look/watch differences.Correct Example: see a bird, look at photo, watch TV

hear/listen differences.Example: I hear noise. I listen to music.
hear/listen differences.Correct Example: I hear noise. I listen to music.

say/tell/speak/talk differences.When to Use: say words, tell someone, speak language, talk to someone
say/tell/speak/talk differences.Example: say hello, tell me, speak English, talk to him
say/tell/speak/talk differences.Correct Example: say hello, tell me, speak English, talk to him

lay/lie differences.Example: lay the book down, lie on bed
lay/lie differences.Correct Example: lay the book down, lie on bed

borrow/lend differences.Example: borrow money from, lend money to
borrow/lend differences.Incorrect Example: He wondered why I am late.
borrow/lend differences.Correct Example: borrow money from, lend money to

its (possessive) vs it's (it is).When to Use: its = belonging to it, it's = it is
its (possessive) vs it's (it is).Incorrect Example: She said that she is happy today.

your (possessive) vs you're (you are).When to Use: your = belonging to you, you're = you are

their/there/they're differences.When to Use: their = possession, there = place, they're = they are
their/there/they're differences.Example: their house, over there, they're coming
their/there/they're differences.Correct Example: their house, over there, they're coming

to/too/two differences.When to Use: to = direction, too = also/excessive, two = number
to/too/two differences.Example: go to school, too hot, two books
to/too/two differences.Correct Example: go to school, too hot, two books

affect (verb) vs effect (noun).Example: It affects me. The effect is bad.
affect (verb) vs effect (noun).Incorrect Example: How many water do you need?
affect (verb) vs effect (noun).Correct Example: It affects me. The effect is bad.

accept (receive) vs except (exclude).When to Use: accept = agree to take, except = not including

beside (next to) vs besides (in addition.English Rule: Beside (next to) vs Besides (in addition to)
beside (next to) vs besides (in addition.When to Use: beside = at the side of, besides = also

use gerund (-ing) after certain verbs.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియల తర్వాత క్రియార్థక నామం (-ing) ఉపయోగించండి
use gerund (-ing) after certain verbs.When to Use: After enjoy, finish, avoid, mind, etc.
use gerund (-ing) after certain verbs.Example: I enjoy reading. She finished working.
use gerund (-ing) after certain verbs.Correct Example: I enjoy reading. She finished working.

use infinitive (to + v1) after certain v.English Rule: Use infinitive (to + V1) after certain verbs
use infinitive (to + v1) after certain v.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియల తర్వాత అవ్యయం (to + V1) ఉపయోగించండి
use infinitive (to + v1) after certain v.When to Use: After want, decide, plan, hope, etc.
use infinitive (to + v1) after certain v.Example: I want to go. She decided to stay.
use infinitive (to + v1) after certain v.Correct Example: I want to go. She decided to stay.

some verbs take both gerund and infiniti.English Rule: Some verbs take both gerund and infinitive with same meaning
some verbs take both gerund and infiniti.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియలు ఒకే అర్థంతో క్రియార్థక నామం మరియు అవ్యయం రెండింటినీ తీసుకుంటాయి
some verbs take both gerund and infiniti.When to Use: With begin, start, continue, like, love, hate
some verbs take both gerund and infiniti.Example: I like reading = I like to read
some verbs take both gerund and infiniti.Correct Example: I like reading = I like to read

some verbs change meaning with gerund vs.English Rule: Some verbs change meaning with gerund vs infinitive
some verbs change meaning with gerund vs.Telugu Rule: కొన్ని క్రియలు క్రియార్థక నామం vs అవ్యయంతో అర్థం మారుతుంది
some verbs change meaning with gerund vs.Example: stop smoking (quit) vs stop to smoke (pause to smoke)
some verbs change meaning with gerund vs.Incorrect Example: Few of the rice is left.
some verbs change meaning with gerund vs.Correct Example: stop smoking (quit) vs stop to smoke (pause to smoke)

use 'enough' before nouns.Incorrect Example: There is a lot of books.

use 'such' with nouns (with adjective).Example: such a beautiful girl, such good food
use 'such' with nouns (with adjective).Correct Example: such a beautiful girl, such good food

countable nouns have singular and plural.English Rule: Countable nouns have singular and plural forms
countable nouns have singular and plural.Telugu Rule: లెక్కించదగిన నామవాచకాలకు ఏకవచనం మరియు బహువచన రూపాలు ఉంటాయి

uncountable nouns have no plural form.English Rule: Uncountable nouns have no plural form

use capital letter for first word of sen.English Rule: Use capital letter for first word of sentence
use capital letter for first word of sen.Telugu Rule: వాక్య మొదటి పదానికి పెద్ద అక్షరం ఉపయోగించండి
use capital letter for first word of sen.Example: The sun rises in the east.
use capital letter for first word of sen.Correct Example: The sun rises in the east.

use capital letters for proper nouns.English Rule: Use capital letters for proper nouns

use capital 'i' for first person pronoun.English Rule: Use capital 'I' for first person pronoun

end questions with question mark (?).Incorrect Example: She is more tall than me.

use exclamation mark (!) for strong emot.English Rule: Use exclamation mark (!) for strong emotion
use exclamation mark (!) for strong emot.Incorrect Example: He is more strong than you.

use comma to separate items in a list.English Rule: Use comma to separate items in a list
use comma to separate items in a list.Telugu Rule: జాబితాలోని అంశాలను వేరు చేయడానికి కామా ఉపయోగించండి
use comma to separate items in a list.Example: I need bread, milk, and eggs.
use comma to separate items in a list.Incorrect Example: This is more easy than that.
use comma to separate items in a list.Correct Example: I need bread, milk, and eggs.

use comma after introductory words/phras.When to Use: After words like however, therefore, etc.

use apostrophe for contractions.Incorrect Example: He is more fast than me.

use apostrophe + s for possession (singu.When to Use: To show ownership by one person/thing
use apostrophe + s for possession (singu.Incorrect Example: She is the most tall girl.

use s + apostrophe for plural possession.English Rule: Use s + apostrophe for plural possession
use s + apostrophe for plural possession.Telugu Rule: బహువచన స్వత్వం కోసం s + అపోస్ట్రఫీ ఉపయోగించండి
use s + apostrophe for plural possession.When to Use: When plural noun already ends in s

use quotation marks for direct speech.English Rule: Use quotation marks for direct speech
use quotation marks for direct speech.Incorrect Example: This is the most cheap phone.

relative clause with 'who' for people.When to Use: To give more information about person
relative clause with 'who' for people.Example: The man who called you is here.
relative clause with 'who' for people.Incorrect Example: She is more better than me.
relative clause with 'who' for people.Correct Example: The man who called you is here.

relative clause with 'which' for things.When to Use: To give more information about thing
relative clause with 'which' for things.Example: The book which I bought is good.
relative clause with 'which' for things.Incorrect Example: He is more worse than you.
relative clause with 'which' for things.Correct Example: The book which I bought is good.

use 'where' for places in relative claus.English Rule: Use 'where' for places in relative clauses
use 'where' for places in relative claus.Example: The hotel where we stayed was nice.
use 'where' for places in relative claus.Incorrect Example: This is more good than that.
use 'where' for places in relative claus.Correct Example: The hotel where we stayed was nice.

use 'when' for time in relative clauses.English Rule: Use 'when' for time in relative clauses
use 'when' for time in relative clauses.Example: The day when I met her was special.
use 'when' for time in relative clauses.Incorrect Example: She is more bad than her.
use 'when' for time in relative clauses.Correct Example: The day when I met her was special.

don't use comma before 'that' in definin.English Rule: Don't use comma before 'that' in defining clauses
don't use comma before 'that' in definin.Example: The book that I need is here.
don't use comma before 'that' in definin.Incorrect Example: He is the most good player.
don't use comma before 'that' in definin.Correct Example: The book that I need is here.

use comma before 'which' in non-defining.English Rule: Use comma before 'which' in non-defining clauses
use comma before 'which' in non-defining.Example: My car, which is red, is fast.
use comma before 'which' in non-defining.Incorrect Example: She is more happy than me.
use comma before 'which' in non-defining.Correct Example: My car, which is red, is fast.

use 'so' to show result.Example: I was tired, so I slept.
use 'so' to show result.Incorrect Example: He runs more fast than me.
use 'so' to show result.Correct Example: I was tired, so I slept.

use 'because' to show reason.Example: I slept because I was tired.
use 'because' to show reason.Correct Example: I slept because I was tired.

use 'although/though' for contrast.Example: Although it rained, we went out.
use 'although/though' for contrast.Incorrect Example: This is more easier than that.
use 'although/though' for contrast.Correct Example: Although it rained, we went out.

use 'but' to contrast within sentence.When to Use: To show opposite in same sentence
use 'but' to contrast within sentence.Example: I like tea but not coffee.
use 'but' to contrast within sentence.Incorrect Example: He is more taller than you.
use 'but' to contrast within sentence.Correct Example: I like tea but not coffee.

tag questions: positive statement + nega.English Rule: Tag questions: positive statement + negative tag
tag questions: positive statement + nega.Telugu Rule: ట్యాగ్ ప్రశ్నలు: సానుకూల ప్రకటన + ప్రతికూల ట్యాగ్

tag questions: negative statement + posi.English Rule: Tag questions: negative statement + positive tag
tag questions: negative statement + posi.Telugu Rule: ట్యాగ్ ప్రశ్నలు: ప్రతికూల ప్రకటన + సానుకూల ట్యాగ్
tag questions: negative statement + posi.Example: You don't like it, do you?
tag questions: negative statement + posi.Incorrect Example: The letter was wrote by her.
tag questions: negative statement + posi.Correct Example: You don't like it, do you?

use 'while' for simultaneous actions.When to Use: When two things happen at same time
use 'while' for simultaneous actions.Incorrect Example: The cake was ate by them.

use 'as soon as' for immediate sequence.English Rule: Use 'as soon as' for immediate sequence
use 'as soon as' for immediate sequence.Example: I'll call you as soon as I arrive.
use 'as soon as' for immediate sequence.Incorrect Example: The problem is solve by him.
use 'as soon as' for immediate sequence.Correct Example: I'll call you as soon as I arrive.

use 'hardly/scarcely' with 'when' for qu.Example: I had hardly arrived when it rained.
use 'hardly/scarcely' with 'when' for qu.Correct Example: I had hardly arrived when it rained.

use 'no sooner...than' for immediate pas.English Rule: Use 'no sooner...than' for immediate past sequence
use 'no sooner...than' for immediate pas.When to Use: For one action immediately after another
use 'no sooner...than' for immediate pas.Example: No sooner had I left than it rained.
use 'no sooner...than' for immediate pas.Incorrect Example: The car is being repaired by mechanic.
use 'no sooner...than' for immediate pas.Correct Example: No sooner had I left than it rained.

use 'either...or' for two positive choic.Example: Either tea or coffee is fine.
use 'either...or' for two positive choic.Incorrect Example: The house has built by them.
use 'either...or' for two positive choic.Correct Example: Either tea or coffee is fine.

use 'neither...nor' for two negative cho.Example: Neither tea nor coffee for me.
use 'neither...nor' for two negative cho.Correct Example: Neither tea nor coffee for me.

use 'not only...but also' for emphasis.Example: He is not only smart but also kind.
use 'not only...but also' for emphasis.Incorrect Example: The song is sung by her.
use 'not only...but also' for emphasis.Correct Example: He is not only smart but also kind.

use 'whether...or' for uncertain alterna.Example: I don't know whether to go or stay.
use 'whether...or' for uncertain alterna.Correct Example: I don't know whether to go or stay.

use 'so that' for purpose.When to Use: To explain why something is done
use 'so that' for purpose.Example: I study so that I can pass.
use 'so that' for purpose.Correct Example: I study so that I can pass.

use 'in order to' for purpose (formal).Example: I came in order to help.
use 'in order to' for purpose (formal).Correct Example: I came in order to help.

use 'in spite of/despite' + noun for con.English Rule: Use 'in spite of/despite' + noun for contrast
use 'in spite of/despite' + noun for con.Incorrect Example: The cake is baking by her.

use 'even if' for hypothetical contrast.Example: Even if it rains, I'll go.
use 'even if' for hypothetical contrast.Incorrect Example: The letter is writing by him.
use 'even if' for hypothetical contrast.Correct Example: Even if it rains, I'll go.

use 'as' for simultaneous actions or com.English Rule: Use 'as' for simultaneous actions or comparison
use 'as' for simultaneous actions or com.When to Use: For things happening together or being similar
use 'as' for simultaneous actions or com.Example: As I walked, I thought. / He is as tall as me.
use 'as' for simultaneous actions or com.Correct Example: As I walked, I thought. / He is as tall as me.

use 'as if/as though' for hypothetical c.English Rule: Use 'as if/as though' for hypothetical comparison
use 'as if/as though' for hypothetical c.Example: He acts as if he knows everything.
use 'as if/as though' for hypothetical c.Incorrect Example: The task will be complete soon.
use 'as if/as though' for hypothetical c.Correct Example: He acts as if he knows everything.

use 'wish' + past for present unreal sit.English Rule: Use 'wish' + past for present unreal situations
use 'wish' + past for present unreal sit.When to Use: For present wishes that aren't true
use 'wish' + past for present unreal sit.Example: I wish I were rich (but I'm not).
use 'wish' + past for present unreal sit.Correct Example: I wish I were rich (but I'm not).

use 'wish' + past perfect for past regre.English Rule: Use 'wish' + past perfect for past regrets
use 'wish' + past perfect for past regre.Example: I wish I had studied (but I didn't).
use 'wish' + past perfect for past regre.Correct Example: I wish I had studied (but I didn't).

use 'would rather' + base verb for prefe.English Rule: Use 'would rather' + base verb for preference

use 'had better' + base verb for strong.English Rule: Use 'had better' + base verb for strong advice
use 'had better' + base verb for strong.Telugu Rule: బలమైన సలహా కోసం 'had better' + మూల క్రియ ఉపయోగించండి

use 'used to' only for past (not present.English Rule: Use 'used to' only for past (not present)
use 'used to' only for past (not present.When to Use: For past habits or states no longer true
use 'used to' only for past (not present.Example: I used to smoke (but not now).
use 'used to' only for past (not present.Correct Example: I used to smoke (but not now).

use 'be used to' + gerund for familiarit.English Rule: Use 'be used to' + gerund for familiarity
use 'be used to' + gerund for familiarit.Telugu Rule: పరిచయానికి 'be used to' + క్రియార్థక నామం ఉపయోగించండి

use 'get used to' + gerund for becoming.English Rule: Use 'get used to' + gerund for becoming familiar
use 'get used to' + gerund for becoming.Telugu Rule: పరిచయం పొందడానికి 'get used to' + క్రియార్థక నామం ఉపయోగించండి
use 'get used to' + gerund for becoming.Example: I'm getting used to the weather.
use 'get used to' + gerund for becoming.Correct Example: I'm getting used to the weather.

use 'make' to force/compel.When to Use: To cause someone to do something

use 'have/get something done' for causat.When to Use: When you arrange for someone to do something

use 'the more...the more' for parallel i.English Rule: Use 'the more...the more' for parallel increase
use 'the more...the more' for parallel i.Example: The more you study, the more you learn.
use 'the more...the more' for parallel i.Correct Example: The more you study, the more you learn.

use 'so do i/neither do i' for agreement.English Rule: Use 'so do I/neither do I' for agreement
use 'so do i/neither do i' for agreement.Telugu Rule: ఏకీభవించడానికి 'so do I/neither do I' ఉపయోగించండి
use 'so do i/neither do i' for agreement.When to Use: To show you agree or have same situation
use 'so do i/neither do i' for agreement.Example: I like it. - So do I. / I don't like it. - Neither do I.
use 'so do i/neither do i' for agreement.Incorrect Example: I remembered to lock the door.
use 'so do i/neither do i' for agreement.Correct Example: I like it. - So do I. / I don't like it. - Neither do I.

use emphatic 'do/does/did' for stress.Example: I do like it (really like it).
use emphatic 'do/does/did' for stress.Incorrect Example: She forgot to meet him yesterday.
use emphatic 'do/does/did' for stress.Correct Example: I do like it (really like it).

use double comparative: more and more/le.English Rule: Use double comparative: more and more/less and less
use double comparative: more and more/le.Telugu Rule: ద్వంద్వ తులనాత్మకం: more and more/less and less ఉపయోగించండి
use double comparative: more and more/le.Example: It's getting more and more difficult.
use double comparative: more and more/le.Correct Example: It's getting more and more difficult.

avoid splitting infinitives when possibl.Example: to quickly run → to run quickly (better)
avoid splitting infinitives when possibl.Correct Example: to quickly run → to run quickly (better)

end sentences with preposition in inform.English Rule: End sentences with preposition in informal speech
end sentences with preposition in inform.Example: Who are you talking to? (informal, acceptable)
end sentences with preposition in inform.Correct Example: Who are you talking to? (informal, acceptable)

use inversion after negative adverbs at.English Rule: Use inversion after negative adverbs at sentence start
use inversion after negative adverbs at.Telugu Rule: వాక్య ప్రారంభంలో ప్రతికూల క్రియా విశేషణాల తర్వాత విలోమం ఉపయోగించండి
use inversion after negative adverbs at.When to Use: After never, seldom, rarely, etc. at start
use inversion after negative adverbs at.Example: Never have I seen such beauty.
use inversion after negative adverbs at.Correct Example: Never have I seen such beauty.

use present tense in time clauses for fu.English Rule: Use present tense in time clauses for future
use present tense in time clauses for fu.Telugu Rule: భవిష్యత్తు కోసం సమయ వాక్యాలలో వర్తమాన కాలం ఉపయోగించండి
use present tense in time clauses for fu.When to Use: After when, before, after, as soon as, etc.
use present tense in time clauses for fu.Example: When I see him, I will tell him.
use present tense in time clauses for fu.Incorrect Example: I'm looking forward to see you.
use present tense in time clauses for fu.Correct Example: When I see him, I will tell him.

use subjunctive 'were' in formal hypothe.Incorrect Example: He is used to wake early.

use 'may' for formal permission, 'can' f.English Rule: Use 'may' for formal permission, 'can' for informal
use 'may' for formal permission, 'can' f.When to Use: may for polite/formal, can for casual
use 'may' for formal permission, 'can' f.Example: May I help you? (formal) / Can I help? (informal)
use 'may' for formal permission, 'can' f.Correct Example: May I help you? (formal) / Can I help? (informal)

use participles as adjectives correctly.When to Use: -ing for causing feeling, -ed for experiencing feeling
use participles as adjectives correctly.Example: boring book (causes boredom), bored person (feels boredom)
use participles as adjectives correctly.Correct Example: boring book (causes boredom), bored person (feels boredom)

maintain parallel structure in lists and.English Rule: Maintain parallel structure in lists and comparisons
maintain parallel structure in lists and.Telugu Rule: జాబితాలు మరియు పోలికలలో సమాంతర నిర్మాణాన్ని నిర్వహించండి
maintain parallel structure in lists and.When to Use: Use same grammatical form for similar elements
maintain parallel structure in lists and.Example: I like reading, writing, and speaking (all -ing forms)
maintain parallel structure in lists and.Incorrect Example: He's good at to play chess.
maintain parallel structure in lists and.Correct Example: I like reading, writing, and speaking (all -ing forms)
